bibl.title: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 2, 1900

div1.p: Reed provides instructions to Emilie Lawrence Reed for garden work at Keewaydin, their Pennsylvania mountain home. He reports that their son, Lawrence, is well.

div1.head: Letter from Walter Reed to Emilie Lawrence Reed, July 2, 1900
div1.opener:
Regards to Cora & Carrie.
No. 11.
Monday Morning.
WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.
Camp Columbia,
Quemados,
Cuba, July 2, '00
My precious wifie:
div1.p:
Saturday's
mail brought me two sweet
letters from my sweet oomsey
& one from darling little cake-
maker- One of yours was post-
marked “Blue Ridge June 27th &
reached here on the 30th-
Pretty quick time that! I cer-
tainly would like to have
peeped in on that scene in
the back-yard described
by you in your letter. I
know that the grapes can't
already be so big as the
circle you drew! Next year
they ought to be beautiful.
How many quarts of straw-
berries did you get from
your patch? They ought to
have borne until about
the end of June- Next year
we will have a larger patch
& if you think of going up
in May, we could get some
that bear in May as well.
Then you could have them
for 8 weeks- Let Jacob now
remove the straw & work over
the bed well- Don't dig too
close to the old plants- About
2 or three runners might be
rooted from each plant- I
will be back in time to see
about transplanting them- Am
glad that the earth has been at
last put on the lawn- The
dear boy was out to see me
yesterday & took lunch & dinner
with me- He isn't as fleshy
as he was, but looks quite
well- His 20 days of exam-
-ination took the flesh off of him.
His class was asked 166 ques-
tions in Mathematics alone! The
examination was indeed pretty
stiff & I think that he deserves
great praise to have stuck to
it so faithfully- He says that
he has had a letter from Mary
Hume in which she called him
my dear Lieutenant- I think that
he would now enjoy going back
to Georgetown once more- I hope
that he may be able to get into
the artillery- Drove down to Ha-
vana, saturday afternoon, & enjoyed
the trip very much- Gen. Wood
will assign a special convey-
ance and driver to our Born,
which will make it very
convenient form us- As far as
weather is concerned, a sum-
mer in Cuba, at this particular
point, is very desirable- It re-
minds me continually of a Sum-
mer resort, especially as the ocean
is in plain view- Yesterday our din-
ner was a good one, with cake
and watermelon & Lawrence seemed
to enjoy it very much- Mrs. Stark will
be caterer during July & promises
to give us a good bill of fare.
How are the rhodedendrons? Blooming?
Am glad to hear, though not surprised,
that Jacob has been such a smart
boy- Always give my regards to him & to
Mr Moore- Did the pay master send you
duplicate notice of your deposit at end of June 2?
Love & kisses for my precious babies.

WAR DEPARTMENT,
SURGEON GENERAL'S OFFICE,
ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM AND LIBRARY,
WASHINGTON.

Would you believe,
lovie, dear, that your
old Mr Mantee overslept
himself, this morning, and that
it is now 6,30 o'clock a,m,?
I have just had my delicious
shower bath and must hurry
& finish my letter before
7 o'clock, as the Postman
comes promptly at that
hour- I can scarcely be-
lieve that it was two(2)
weeks ago, this afternoon,
that I said good-bye to
Fat Farmer lady & plump
piano-player at dear Kee-
waydin- The time here sim-
ply flies- I never saw
anything like it- While I
think of it, and to return
to farming, I think that if
it becomes dry, you will
have to let Jacob pull
some of the leaves & manure
back around the little fruit-
trees, as it serves as a
mulch & to protect their
roots in hot weather.
It was all right to have
them nicely worked around
and you were a dear, smart
farmer lady to have thought
about it. Now, lovie, dear,
you know that the supposed
Holy-hock that I planted
was not a Squash? What
kind of a squash? Not a
regular, old fashioned cim-
lin? I don't believe it!
The word “rustler” is
proper & in correct form,
but it does not sufficient-
ly describe Johnnie Moore's
movements- You should have
said that he was a Hust-
ler from Hustlerville!
How does the fence look, now
that he has built a con-
siderable part of it?
Be certain to point out
to him that beautiful plant,
and don't let him destroy
it- Am glad that auntie
will soon be on the Mountain.
you never told me what
decision Mr Moore came
too as to the pony- Did he
take it? or did you return
it to Cap't. Norwood? Has
Blossom returned Mary's
call yet? She certainly should
do it- I know that your
morning at dear Keewaydin
cannot be any more beau-
tiful than it is here, this
morning, and the beautiful,
blue ocean is so lovely
to look at- You must come
down & take a peep next
January- It's nearly seven,
Love & Kisses for my sweet
Farmer lady and dear little
chicken-raiser- Regards to
Jacob, Cora & Carrie- write-often.
Boo! Boo!
